growing.zone: 2-10 (varies by variety; American and French-American more cold-hardy, European prefer warmer zones)
growing.sun: Full sun (at least 7-8 hours per day for best fruit production)
growing.water: Moderate; drought-tolerant once established but benefits from regular watering during dry spells, especially during fruiting
growing.soil: Slightly acidic (pH 5.5-7), deep, well-drained, loose; prefers sandy loam or loamy soil

planting.height: Varies by training method; vines can reach 6-12 feet or more when trellised
planting.spacing: 6-10 feet apart depending on variety and training system
planting.whenToPlant: Early spring after the last hard freeze; soak bare roots for 2-3 hours before planting
planting.propagation: Usually by dormant cuttings or grafted plants; seeds rarely used due to variability
planting.depth: Plant about 1 foot deep; set graft or crown at soil level or just above
avoidPlantingNear: Nightshades (can increase risk of shared diseases)
Black walnut (produces juglone which may inhibit grape growth)

pruning: Annual pruning is essential; prune in late winter to control vine growth and encourage fruit production
Remove up to 90% of the previous year's growth, keeping only a few strong canes and renewal spurs
careAndMaintenance.stakingSupport: Trellis, arbor, or pergola needed to support vines and improve air circulation
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: In colder zones, mulch base and protect young vines with burlap or covers to prevent winter injury

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: When grapes are rich in color, plump, and flavorful; they will not continue to ripen once picked
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Cut entire clusters with pruning shears to avoid damaging the vine
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Fresh eating, juicing, wine, jams, jellies, raisins (drying)

pollinators: Most cultivated varieties are self-fertile; pollinated by wind and insects
wildlifeResistance: Birds and mammals such as raccoons may eat fruit; netting or fencing may be necessary

American.description: Cold-hardy and disease-resistant; commonly used for juice and jelly (e.g., Concord)

European.description: Prefers warm, dry climates; prized for winemaking and table grapes (e.g., Thompson Seedless)

French-American.description: Hybrids that combine cold-hardiness and disease resistance of American grapes with some flavor qualities of European types
